body_text.text: Keep Calm and Nightingale on Q1 X XD 1 X XJessica L. Peck, D 2 X XDNP, APRN, CPNP-PC, CNE, CNL, FAANP As I write, the world is experiencing an unprecedented health crisis as the coronavirus disease of 2019 pandemic spreads throughout 2020, the Year of the Nurse. Nurses are ranked annually by the American public as the most trusted professionals. We are the most innovative, resilient, caring, and tenacious profession that has ever existed. Nursing will always find a way to rise and meet the challenges of tomorrow.

As advanced practice nurses, we find ourselves in the epicenter of this worldwide crisis, ideally situated as nursing leaders to engage and equip communities. The National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) is recognized as the global leader, trusted authority, and indispensable resource on comprehensive pediatric advanced practice nursing. The mission of our organization is to empower you to positively impact child and family health outcomes, especially in times like this.

In this time, when the nursing voice is paramount, we need to own our expertise. We know how to assess, diagnose, treat, and prescribe therapies. We know how to engage, equip, and empower families to become stronger and healthier. We know how to use our voices as policy advocates, our eyes, and hands as competent caregivers, our minds as teachers and scholars, and our hearts to clothe these efforts in compassion, strength, and resilience. As the most disruptive innovation in 21st-century health care, nurse practitioners have a calling to provide high quality, accessible, affordable care, especially to the most vulnerable among usour children. It will take extraordinary courage to impact the issues facing pediatric health care today. As a unified profession, it will take our collective efforts, our acquired knowledge, our applied wisdom, and our unwavering dedication to fearlessly do whatever it takes to be a voice of advocacy for children all over the world.

Our profession often requires grueling work, which costs us physically, mentally, and emotionally. We practice in a world where our families struggle at times to understand burdens we bear, our education is diminished, our moral distress is present in decision-making, our bodies and minds are tired, and our voices are silenced. Nurses often put the needs of others above our own needs, to our detriment at times, being mindful of the Nightingale Pledge to "dedicate ourselves to devoted service to human welfare" and to do "all in our power to elevate the standard of our profession" (Nightingale Pledge, 1985, p. 18) .
These are, as many have said, uncertain times. However, I am certain the test of this pandemic will reinforce the strengths of nursing, and we will come through this stronger together.

And so, we press on. Despite the dangers, we are there in the most fragile and vulnerable times during human life. We meet indignities with the utmost dignity and compassion. We keep confidences without judgment. We honor wishes and protect autonomy. We cheer progress even when the end seems endless. We serve daily doses of hope in the face of utter hopelessness. We wipe tears of strangers and hug broken human spirits. We care for people when they cannot care for themselves. We are calm in the face of fear. We are comfort in the midst of pain. We face difficult things straight on, head up, and eyes clear, although we take a moment to cry in the parking lot before we drive home to care for our own families. As I recently saw quoted in the Second World War museum, "The difficult, we do now. The impossible takes a little longer" (Naval History & Heritage Command, 2018, Paragraph 5).

So, I salute you. And I challenge you. Be kind to yourself. Be intentional. Be a caretaker of your mental health. Be a scholar. Be a lifelong student. Be a leader. Be a servant. Be a teacher. Be excellent. Be unafraid to take on the impossible. Be proud of your profession. Defend it. Celebrate diversity among our ranks. Be courageous. Be an advocate-for your patients and yourself. NAPNAP is an organization unafraid to engage in difficult conversations. You have joined more than 9,000 voices with courage in the face of darkness. Nelson Mandela said, "I learned courage was not the absence of fear, but the triumph over it" (Nsehe, 2013, Paragraph 2) .

How very little can be done under the spirit of fear. I am of certain convinced that the greatest heroes are those who do their duty in the daily grind of domestic affairs whilst the world whirls as a maddening dreidel.

It will take extraordinary courage to impact the issues facing pediatric health care today. It will take our collective efforts, our acquired knowledge, our applied wisdom, and our unwavering dedication to fearlessly do whatever it takes to be a voice of advocacy for children all over the world. NAPNAP is here to support you in leading these efforts. I look forward to the journey ahead.
